paper.title: Exploiting mixed-frequency characteristics in parametric Mean-Expected Shortfall portfolio selection
paper.abstract: In this paper, we investigate the role of mixed-frequency characteristics in portfolio selection. We introduce novel parametric Mean-Expected Shortfall model which establishes direct linkages between portfolio weights and mixed-frequency characteristics. The model solution is converted into a penalized MIDAS expectile regression problem, which not only reduces computational costs, but also identifies the crucial characteristics. An empirical analysis of the CSI 300 index reveals that incorporating mixed-frequency characteristics significantly enhances portfolio performance. The proposed method consistently outperforms other competing models by delivering substantially lower risk and markedly higher risk-adjusted returns. Further coefficient analysis highlights crucial characteristics exerting significant impacts on portfolio weights. Specifically, accumulation distribution and market value demonstrate positive influences, while moving averages, relative strength index, liquidity, and book-to-market ratio exhibit negative impacts. These findings provide investors with valuable tool for asset allocation, enhancing interpretability and reliability in complex data environments.

domain_result.justification: 该论文的核心技术是提出了一种新的参数化均值-预期短缺模型，用于优化投资组合选择，并实证分析了其在CSI 300指数上的表现，显著提升了投资组合的风险调整后收益。这些内容直接关联到投资组合管理的核心问题。
